Temperature: Temperature decreases as the level of greenhouse effect decreases.  Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.
CO2: Fewer volcanoes dump less CO2 into the atmosphere.  Because the carbon sinks take a long time to react (~100,000 years), CO2 sinks exceed CO2 sources, causing the atmospheric CO2 level to decrease.  However, it will take longer than 200 years for CO2 to change signficantly.
Volcano: A decrease in volcanic activity is the forcer in this scenario, declining from level 4 to level 3 in 100-200 years to show that the process is underway.  This is much faster than a real volcano down scenario (they usually decline over several tens of millions of years).
Ice: Dropping temperatures will cause ice accumulation.
Sea: Deciling temperature lower sea level quickly, but in 200 years temperature has not changed much. Accumulating glacial ice and volcanic activity also lower sea level, but response times are longer.
Weathering C Burial: Decreasing temperature lower evaporation and precipitation, which lower weathering rates.  However, it will take >200 years to respond.
CO3 Desposition: Decreasing weathering rates lower carbonate deposition less C and Ca are washed to the oceans), but response times are long (~100,000 years)
Sediment: C burial by sediments, buried C release, Insolation, and Mountains likely won't change enough to have an effect in this scenario.

Temperature: Temperature decreases as the level of greenhouse effect decreases.  Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.
CO2: Fewer volcanoes dump less CO2 into the atmosphere.  Because the carbon sinks take a long time to react (~100,000 years), CO2 sinks exceed CO2 sources, causing the atmospheric CO2 level to decrease.
Volcano: The decrease in volcanic activity continues at a slow, steady rate.   The decrease from 4 to 3 occurs over the entire 100,000 year interval--it was shown in the 100-200 year interval to show that the process was underway.
Ice: Polar ice begins to form as temperature drops
Sea: Sea level drops as polar ice forms (removing water from the oceans), as sea temperature drops (due to thermal contraction) and mid-ocean ridges decrease in both height and coverage as volcanoes decrease.
Weathering C Burial: Decreasing temperature lower evaporation and precipitation, which lower weathering rates.  It responds in this time scale.
CO3 Desposition: Decreasing weathering rates lower carbonate deposition less C and Ca are washed to the oceans), it responds in this time scale.

Ice: Polar ice begins to form as temperature drops

Temperature: Temperature decreases as the level of greenhouse effect decreases.
CO2: Fewer volcanoes dump less CO2 into the atmosphere.  Because the carbon sinks take a long time to react (~100,000 years), CO2 sinks still exceed CO2 sources, causing the atmospheric CO2 level to decrease.
Volcano: Volcanoes decrease to level 2 during this time scale.  This is the lowest level assumed in this scenario

Temperature: Temperature responds quickly to CO2 level.  Since CO2 level is at equilibrium, temperature also settle into equilibrium.
CO2: CO2 sources and sinks have now come into equilibrium at a new, lower level.
Volcano: Volcanoes remain level 2 during this time scale, the lowest level assumed in this scenario
Ice: Polar ice continues to grow during this time scale due to the ice-albedo effect.  It reaches equilibrium at level 4.
Sea: Because polar ice grew during this time scale, sea level also dropped.
Weathering C Burial: Because temperature (and mountains) remained consistent through this period, weathering and carbonate deposition also remained consistent.  Carbon removal (through carbonate deposition) in now in balance with the lower volcanic CO2 source.
